coredata.dc:title: Precisely engineering the electronic structure of active sites boosts the activity of iron-nickel selenide on nickel foam for highly efficient and stable overall water splitting

coredata.dc:description: The development of efficient and stable electrocatalysts to speed up the sluggish kinetics of water splitting has long been being the frontier of energy conversion research. Herein, we report a highly efficient electrocatalyst of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 prepared on nickel foam for overall water splitting. The optimal P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 electrode exhibits an extremely low overpotential of 156 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 226 mV at 300 mA cm−2 for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the highly efficient activity remains stable for up to 1000 h at 300 mA cm−2. More importantly, the water-alkali electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 requires only 1.45 V and 1.82 V to reach current densities of 10 and 300 mA cm−2, respectively, outperforming that of RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2. Systematically theoretical and experimental results reveal that P doping can independently modulate the electronic structure of Fe without affecting Ni, optimize the adsorption strength of OER intermediates at active sites and consequently facilitate the OER kinetics.

head.ce:title: Precisely engineering the electronic structure of active sites boosts the activity of iron-nickel selenide on nickel foam for highly efficient and stable overall water splitting

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The development of efficient and stable electrocatalysts to speed up the sluggish kinetics of water splitting has long been being the frontier of energy conversion research. Herein, we report a highly efficient electrocatalyst of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 prepared on nickel foam for overall water splitting. The optimal P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 electrode exhibits an extremely low overpotential of 156 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and 226 mV at 300 mA cm−2 for oxygen evolution reaction (OER) and the highly efficient activity remains stable for up to 1000 h at 300 mA cm−2. More importantly, the water-alkali electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 requires only 1.45 V and 1.82 V to reach current densities of 10 and 300 mA cm−2, respectively, outperforming that of RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2. Systematically theoretical and experimental results reveal that P doping can independently modulate the electronic structure of Fe without affecting Ni, optimize the adsorption strength of OER intermediates at active sites and consequently facilitate the OER kinetics.

ce:section.ce:para: Electrochemical water splitting has been considered to be a promising energy technology for the storage of renewable and sustainable energy (solar energy, wind, etc.) and the generation of chemical fuels (hydrogen gas, methanol, etc.) [1,2]. As one key half-reaction and the bottleneck of water splitting, the oxygen evolution reaction (OER) at the anode is intrinsically sluggish involved a four-proton-coupled electron transfer process [3]. To date, transition metal chalcogenides have been attracting increasingly considerable interest for OER due to their low cost, environmental friendliness, high abundance, and potentially high activity [4]. Compared with oxides, chalcogenides possess higher conductivity, more varied valence states and phases, and abundant redox chemistry [5]. For example, NiSe (2630 S cm−1) exhibits a few orders of magnitude higher conductivity than NiO (0.01–0.32 S cm−1) [6,7]. Recently, NiFe-selenides have been demonstrated as efficient electrocatalysts for OER due to the potentially optimal adsorption energy of OER intermediates and adjustable electronic structure [8]. The best NiFe-selenides electrode reported so far enabled a current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low overpotential of 195 mV, comparable to the noble metal-based electrodes [9]. However, most NiFe-selenides electrodes delivered an overpotential of at least 200 mV, and furthermore, the current stability (10 mA cm−2) was maintained for only dozens of hours, let alone a larger current density for hundreds of hours [8,10]. One of the major intrinsic obstacles that restrict the electrocatalytic efficiency of NiFe-selenides electrode for water splitting is the non-optimized electronic structure for electron transfer and the adsorption/desorption of intermediates [8,11].

Compared with single metal catalysts, the binary/multi-metal catalysts can supply a more complex electronic structure of active sites and enable higher flexibility to tune the process of the adsorption and desorption of intermediates [12,13]. According to the d-band center theory, the adsorption energy of oxygen-containing intermediates can be effectively adjusted by combining Ir/Ru with 3d transition metals [14–17]. For instance, the introduction of Ni can effectively modulate the electronic structure and downshift the d-band center of the Ru-Ni electrocatalysts for easier O-O the bond formation, thereby promoting OER activity [14]. Except for optimizing the adsorption energy of OER oxo-intermediates, alloying Ru with Sr and Ir can substantially suppress the participation of lattice oxygen during OER, preventing the dissolution of the electrocatalyst [15]. NiFe-selenide, as an intriguing alternative to noble metal catalysts, exhibited optimal adsorption of oxygen intermediates which was proved to be closely related to the synergistic effects of Ni and Fe [8,12,18–20]. Additionally, although the nickel-iron (Ni-Fe)-based bimetal electrocatalysts exhibit remarkable OER performance, the roles that Ni and Fe play in catalyzing water oxidation is still under debate [21]. The results reported so far reveal that the electronic structures of Ni and Fe integrally contribute to the enhanced OER activity and therefore precisely controlling and understanding their electronic structures is of key importance to unveil the pathways involved. Herein, we report P doped Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 nanosheets on Ni foam as a highly efficient and stable electrode for overall water splitting and show the attainability of precisely tuning the electronic structure of NiFe-selenides. The as-prepared P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 catalyst displayed a low overpotential of 156 mV at 10 mA cm−2 and worked stably for at least 1000 h at 300 mA cm−2. Inspiringly, the water-alkali electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 exhibited a relatively low cell voltage of 1.45 V to reach 10 mA cm−2 and excellent durability at a relatively high current density of 100 mA cm−2 for at least 1000 h.

Nickel foam (NF), Nickel nitrate hexahydrate (Ni(NO3)2·6H2O), ferrous sulfate heptahydrate (FeSO4·7H2O), ammonium fluoride (NH4F), sodium borohydride (NaBH4), potassium hydroxide (KOH), sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2), ammonium molybdate ((NH4)6Mo7O24·6H2O) urea, ethanol, and acetone were obtained from National Reagent Company. Commercial RuO2, Nafion (5 wt%), and Se powder were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. All the chemicals were used without further purification.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of NiFe LDH on nickel foam (NiFe LDH)
ce:section.ce:para: Typically, 1 mM Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, 0.4 mM FeSO4·7H2O, 8 mM urea, and 5 mM NH4F were firstly dissolved in deionized water and transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless autoclave with a cleaned NF. The hydrothermal reaction was carried out at 120 °C for 16 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained NiFe LDH was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, respectively, and then dried in a vacuum oven for use.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 on nickel foam (Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2)
ce:section.ce:para: Firstly, 65 mg Se powder and 65 mg NaBH4 were added into 30 mL deionized water under N2 flow while stirring to obtain a NaHSe solution. Then the prepared solution with a dried NiFe LDH on NF was put into a 50 mL autoclave, and the hydrothermal reaction was carried out at 180 °C for 20 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, respectively, and dried in a vacuum oven.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 on nickel foam (P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2)
ce:section.ce:para: For P doping, a piece of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 on NF was immersed in a solution containing 0.1 M NaH2PO2 for 10 min. Then the sample of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was dried and annealed at 500 °C for 60 min under Ar flow with a heating rate of 5 °C min−1. After cooling to room temperature, the final product was obtained and kept in a vacuum oven for use.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Synthesis of MoNi4/MoO2 on nickel foam (MoNi4/MoO2)
ce:section.ce:para: The electrode of MoNi4/MoO2 on nickel foam was prepared according to a previous report [22]. Typically, 0.6 mM Ni(NO3)2·6H2O and 0.15 mM (NH4)6Mo7O24·6H2O were dissolved in deionized water, and then the obtained solution with a cleaned NF was transferred into a Teflon autoclave for the hydrothermal reaction at 150 °C for 6 h. After cooling to room temperature, the obtained NiMoO4 cuboids on nickel foam were washed three times with deionized water and ethanol, respectively. Finally, the NiMoO4 cuboids were heated to 500 °C for 2 h in H2/Ar (10%) atmosphere to obtain MoNi4/MoO2.

Crystal structure data of different samples were collected on Bruker D8 Advance Powder X-ray diffractometer with a Cu Kα X-ray source (λ = 0.15406 nm). The SEM images were recorded on a HITACHI S-4800 field emission scanning electron microscope. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) measurements were carried out using JEOL JEM 2100. The chemical valence state of the obtained products was measured by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS, Thermo Scientific ESCALab 250). Temperature-dependent conductivity was performed using a Quantum Design PPMS DynaCool-9 magnetometer. The chemical composition of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) using an Agilent ICP-OES730.

All the OER electrochemical tests were performed according to our previous report [23]. The electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) measurements were carried out in 1 M KOH within a frequency range from 0.01 to 105 Hz at a potential of 1.42 V (V vs. RHE), whereas the AC amplitude voltage was set to be 5 mV. For HER measurements, the reference electrode was a double salt bridge Ag/AgCl electrode and the counter electrode was a graphite rod. Overall water splitting measurements were performed using a two-electrode system in 1 M KOH.

For comparison, 5 mg of RuO2 was ultrasonically dispersed in a mixture of 550 μL of ethanol, 450 μL of water, and 50 μL of 5% Nafion, and the dispersion was transferred to a nickel foam substrate electrode for electrochemical measurement.

The mass activity (A g−1) of different catalysts was calculated according to the following formula:
Mass activity = j/m
Here, m is the catalyst loading amount (mg cm−2) and j is the measured current density (mA cm−2) from LSV polarization curves at the overpotential of 250 mV.

The TOF values of different catalysts were estimated according to the following formula:
TOF = j*S/(4*F*n)

where j (mA cm−2) is the measured current density from LSV polarization curves at an overpotential of 250 mV, S (1 * 1 cm2) is the geometric surface area of the as-prepared electrode, F is Faraday’s constant (96485.3 C mol−1), and n is the mole of active metal sites calculated by the catalyst loading amount.

To gain understanding for the effect of P element on the catalytic process, the models on the (210) facet of NiFeSe2 and P-doped NiFeSe2 (denoted as P-NiFeSe2) were constructed according to the previous report [24–26]. All the structures are shown in Fig. S1. The free energy simulation of OER systems were carried out by the Vienna Ab-initio Simulation Package (VASP) [27–30], taking advantage of the density functional theory (DFT) with the Projected Augmented Wave (PAW) method. The LDA+U method was employed to describe the nature of the d electrons of Ni and Fe, in which the effective U-J values are 3.4 eV for Ni and 3.3 eV for Fe [31]. The Perdew-Burke-Ernzerhof (PBE) functional was used to describe the exchange and correlation effects. For the geometry optimizations of the pristine catalysts, lattice relaxation for the crystal structure was performed. The cutoff energy was set to be 600 eV. The Gamma-only k-point mesh was adopted for performing the calculations. For the geometry optimizations of another system, the cell lattice was fixed as the result of the previous lattice relaxation calculations. The energy cutoff was set to be 400 eV. For all the systems, a 30 Å vacuum thickness was added along the z-direction of the simulation box, preventing the interactions between the adjacent slabs.

In alkaline condition, the OER could occur in the following 4 elementary steps:
OH– + * → *OH + e–
OH– + *OH → *O + H2O + e–
OH– + *O → *OOH + e–
OH– + *OOH → * + O2 + H2O + e–
where * denotes the active sites on the catalyst surface. Based on the above mechanism, the free energy of 3 intermediate states (OOH*, OH*, and O*) is important to identify the OER performance of a target material. The computational hydrogen electrode (CHE) model proposed by Nørskov et al. [32] was used to calculate the free energies of OER intermediates, based on which the free energy of an adsorbed species is defined as below.

Density functional theory (DFT) simulations were firstly performed to study the effect of P doping on the intrinsic catalytic activity of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 for OER. P-doping is simulated by substituting Se with P. The corresponding theoretical crystal structure models and the intermediates including OH*, O*, and OOH* after being optimized of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 are shown in Fig. 1(a) and Fig. S1. The free energy-change profile for each intermediate on Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 reveals that the step O* to OOH* exhibits the largest energy barrier for the two models (Fig. 1a and Table S1), consistent with previous reports [20,33,34]. The potential rate-limiting step for Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 exhibits a high energy barrier of 2.09 eV with an overpotential of 0.86 V. In contrast, the energy barrier and overpotential are substantially reduced to 1.97 eV and 0.74 V after P doping, suggesting P-doping on Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 significantly facilitate the OER process. In order to gain more insights into the enhanced OER performance, the charge density difference calculation was carried out to investigate the changes in the electronic structure of Ni and Fe after P doping [35]. As shown in Fig. 1(b) and (c), the charge density difference indicates that P doping has induced considerable charge accumulation around Fe atoms via electron transfer from P to Fe while there is negligible influence on Ni atoms, confirmed by Bader analysis (Fig. S2-S3 and Table S2). The above theoretical results predict that P doping to Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 can modulate the electronic structure of Fe independently and boost the OER activity of the resulting electrode.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Preparation and characterization of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 catalyst
ce:section.ce:para: According to the theoretical prediction, the P doped Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 nanosheets on nickel foam were synthesized as depicted in Fig. 2(a). Typically, layered NiFe LDH (Ni0.75Fe0.25(CO3)0.125(OH)2·0.38 H2O, JCPDS No. 40–0215) nanosheets were first prepared on nickel foam, confirmed by the X-ray powder diffraction (XRD, Fig. S4-S6). The scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Fig. S7) image indicates that the lateral size of the nanosheets is several micrometers with a thickness of 20–40 nm. Subsequently, NiFe LDH was selenized via a hydrothermal method and the morphology was well preserved (Fig. S8). To achieve P doping, a piece of nickel foam with Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was immersed into a NaH2PO2 solution and then annealed in Ar at 500 °C after washing and drying. The products exhibit a similar structure to the standard cubic NiSe2 (JCPDS No. 41-1495) as shown in Fig. 2(c) and the XRD diﬀraction peaks (Fig. 2b and S9) at 30.0°, 33.6°, 36.9°, 42.9°, 50.8°, 55.5°, and 57.8° can be well indexed to the (200), (210), (211), (220), (311), (230), and (321) facets except for the slight shift due to the larger atomic radius of Fe [9,36]. Although P doping displayed no effect on the crystal structure of the products due to the low P content, the morphology was changed substantially. After P doping, the surface of nanosheets becomes much rougher decorated with smaller nanosheets and particles (Fig. 2d–e and Fig. S10), which is beneficial to maximizing the number of active sites and accelerating the mass transport between electrode and electrolyte. The observation by transmission electron microscopy (TEM) confirmed the morphology (Fig. 2f) and the observed d-spacing of 0.26 nm can be indexed to (210) crystal planes of cubic P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (Fig. 2g). The elemental mapping images (Fig. 2h) suggest the uniform distribution of Ni, Fe, Se, and P elements throughout P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 nanosheets. The P content can be readily tuned by controlling the concentration of sodium hypophosphite (NaH2PO2) solution and soaking time (Table S3). The P doping content of the optimized P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was 0.29% with a ratio of Fe/Ni ~1/3, consistent with the XRD result. These results indicate that the desired P doped ferric nickel selenide has been successfully obtained on nickel foam.

ce:section.ce:section-title: XPS characterization of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 before and after P doping
ce:section.ce:para: X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) also confirms the presence of P in the resulting product as well as the modulation of the electronic structure of Fe ( Fig. 3). For the P 2p spectrum (Fig. 3a), a peak at 128.6 eV is ascribed to the formation of the P-M (Fe and Ni) bond and the stronger peak at 133.4 eV is related to phosphate (P–O) due to surface oxidation in the air [37,38]. In the region of Fe 2p (Fig. 3b), the peaks at 712.1 and 725.4 eV attributed to Fe3+ shifting distinctly (~ 0.4 eV) towards lower binding energy after P doping because of the electron transfer from P to Fe [18,23,37,38], coincident with the theoretical result, while no peak shift was observed for the spectrum of Ni 2p (Fig. 3c) [20,23,38,39]. For Se 3d (Fig. 3d), the peaks at ~54.9 and 58.8 eV can be assigned to Se-M (Fe/Ni) bonding and Se-O bonding due to surface oxidation, similar to the results of P 2p [9,18,23,36].

In order to study the effect of P doping on Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2, the OER performance was evaluated in a typical three-electrode cell. Compared with Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (183 mV) and RuO2 (275 mV), the overpotential of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was considerably reduced to 156 mV at the current density of 10 mA cm−2 ( Fig. 4a). As shown in the inset of Fig. 4(a), the enhanced catalytic activity of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was also reflected by its low Tafel slope of 19.5 mV dec−1, much smaller than those of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (26.5 mV dec−1) and RuO2 (33.7 mV dec−1), confirming the rapid reaction kinetics after P doping [37,38]. The outstanding OER performance of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 can compete with or even outperform previously reported analogues and noble metal-based catalysts such as NixFe1−xSe2-DO [9], NiFe LDH [40], (NiFe)PS3 [41], S-NiFe2O4 [42] (Fig. 4b and Table S4) [43–46]. In particular, the mass activity of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 approaches 314.81 A g−1 at an overpotential of 250 mV (Fig. 4c and Table S5), which is about 25 times and twice higher than RuO2 (12.37 A g−1) and Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (102.90 A g−1), respectively. Besides, the mass activity of our as-synthesized P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 is comparable or better than most transition metal-based catalysts such as IrO2 (27.5 A g−1) [1], Ni0.75Fe0.25OOH (117 A g−1) [1], and γ-CoOOH nanosheets (66.6 A g−1) [47] at an overpotential of 300 mV. The calculated turnover frequency (TOF, Fig. 4d and Table S5) of the samples increases as the overpotential increases and the TOF of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 reaches 0.18 s−1 at an overpotential of 250 mV, 6 times and 18 times higher than Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (0.03 s−1) and RuO2 (0.01 s−1). Furthermore, the TOF of our as-synthesized P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 is superior to other analogues such as Cu3Mo2O9 (0.02 s−1) [48], Co4Ni1P (0.032 s−1) [49], CoP (0.014 s−1) [49], Ni2P (0.0082 s−1) [49], and NiO/Fetrace (0.03 s−1) [50] at an overpotential of 300 mV. In addition to OER activity, the durability of catalysts is another key parameter for large-scale commercial applications. The multi-chronopotentiometry test from 10 to 300 mA cm−2 revealed that P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 can work stably at different current densities with negligible degradation (Fig. 4e). Furthermore, P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 showed only a slight increase in potential after running for over 1000 h at a relatively high current density of 300 mA cm−2 (Fig. 4f). The above results demonstrated that the P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 nanosheets exhibited remarkable OER activity and stability, unambiguously superior to analogues reported so far (Table S4). Furthermore, the result of XRD indicated that the crystal structure of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 after the OER stability test remained unchanged (Fig. S11), consistent with the well-preserved morphology (Fig. S12). The binding energy of Fe 2p and Ni 2p is slightly shifted to higher energy due to the partial oxidation to form metal oxide/hydroxide species on the surface of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (Fig. S13), consistent with previous reports on metal chalcogenides for the OER catalytic process [9,18,20,23,38]. Although an obvious increase in the amount of Se-O and P-O bonds was observed due to the oxidation of Se-M and P-M bonds, the Se-M and P-M species are well preserved. It has been reported that the formation of P-O species on the surface of electrocatalysts not only is beneficial to improving the OER electrocatalytic activity by accelerating charge transfer between active metallic centers and oxygen-containing intermediates, but also can serve as a passivation layer to prevent leaching out of Se and active metallic center (Fe or Ni) for selenides during OER, contributive to the long-term stability [51,52]. These results further suggest that the P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 catalyst manifested outstanding electrochemical and structural stability during the long-term OER process.

The enhanced performance was further analyzed by the electrochemical double-layer capacitances (Cdl) calculated to reflect the electrochemically active surface area (ECSA) toward OER (Fig. S14) [13]. The Cdl of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 is 3.29 mF cm−2, much higher than 2.45 mF cm−2 for Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and 1.48 mF cm−2 for RuO2 ( Fig. 5a), illustrating that the improved catalytic activity of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 is partly ascribed to the increased number of active sites. When the LSV curves were normalized by ECSA (Fig. 5b), P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 still possesses lower overpotentials than Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and RuO2. This result suggests that P doping not only created new active sites but also enhanced the intrinsic activity, consolidating the theoretical simulation [53]. In addition, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) indicated that P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (7.66 Ω) displayed a smaller charge-transfer resistance than RuO2 (14.20 Ω) and Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (12.80 Ω), confirming the faster electron transportation during the OER process (Fig. 5c and Table S6), consistent with Tafel analysis. The study on the electrical behavior between resistivity and temperature revealed that the conductivity of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was significantly enhanced after P doping (Fig. 5d). For instance, P doping enabled an improvement in conductivity from 169.60 S cm−1 to 297.22 S cm−1 at 300 K, indicative of improved electron transportation in the bulk. However, the conductivity gradually increases as the temperature increases even after P doping, reflecting the semiconducting nature of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 [54].

As expected, the current was apparently enhanced when the electrode was illuminated in light (Fig. 5e), suggesting that the charge transfer in the bulk is still a limit factor for the OER performance [55]. Improving the bulk conductivity of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 by doping, alloying and vacancy engineering may allow for further improvement of its OER activity [56–59]. Additionally, compared with our previous results [59], the conductivity of the substrate is also critical, confirmed by considerably improved performance when carbon cloth was replaced with nickel foam (Fig. S15). Last but not least, the adsorption strength of OH* on P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 was investigated based on the Laviron equation [60]. The redox constant of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (0.11 s−1) is nearly twice greater than that of Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 (0.06 s−1) (Fig. 5f and Fig. S16), indicating that P doping promoted the formation of OH* intermediate and optimized the intermediate adsorption strength on P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 during OER [60–62]. These results unambiguously prove that P doping can significantly facilitate OER catalytic processes by apparently (a) increasing the number of active sites, (b) improving the conductivity, (c) reducing the charge-transfer resistance, (d) optimizing the adsorption strength of OER intermediates.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Evaluation of electrocatalytic activity for overall water splitting
ce:section.ce:para: Inspired by the superior activity and durability of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 toward OER, a water-alkali electrolyzer was assembled to evaluate its potential application for hydrogen production via water splitting. A previously reported electrode of MoNi4/MoO2 on Ni foam [22] was prepared as an cathode for hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) and the as-prepared P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 on Ni foam was used directly as a anode (denoted as P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2). Notably, the electrode of MoNi4/MoO2 exhibited outstanding HER performance with an ultralow overpotential of 78 mV to deliver a current density of 100 mA cm−2 (Fig. S17). For comparison, an electrode of commercial RuO2 on Ni foam was fabricated as an anode and coupled with MoNi4/MoO2 (denoted as RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2).

Intriguingly, the electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 exhibits superior performance with a small cell voltage of 1.61 V to deliver a current density of 100 mA cm−2 ( Fig. 6a), surpassing RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2 (1.76 V). The cell voltage (1.45 V) of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 is even much lower than those of many reported promising materials such as Ir/C || Pt/C (1.67 V) [22], NiSe-Ni0.85Se || NiSe-Ni0.85Se (1.62 V) [63], FeCoNiP0.5S0.5 || FeCoNiP0S1 (1.46 V) [64] (Table S7). By monitoring the gas production and comparing it with the current, a Faradaic efficiency of about 97% was obtained (Fig. 6b), indicating that the observed current over the catalyst exclusively originated from OER rather than other processes. More importantly, the electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 can steadily work at a relatively high current density of 100 mA cm−2 for at least 1000 h without perceptible degradation, while the electrolyzer of RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2 worked stably only less than 50 h with the cell voltage increased obviously (Fig. 6c). The impressive performance of the electrolyzer made from P-Ni075Fe0.25Se2 for overall water splitting outperforms most of the recently reported ones such as FeNiOOH(Se)/IF || MoNi4/MoO2/IF [53], NiSe/NF || NiSe/NF [65], and FeSe2/NF || FeSe2/NF [66] in activity and stability (Table S7). Finally, the water-alkali electrolyzer of P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 || MoNi4/MoO2 was integrated with a commercial dry battery to drive the water-splitting system in 1 M KOH. Fig. 6(d) shows photographs of the commercial dry battery (1.5 V) assisted water splitting device, and continuous O2 and H2 bubbles can be observed on the surface of both electrodes. Such a dry battery-assisted water splitting device demonstrates the feasibility of the P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 electrode for converting low-voltage electrical energy into chemical fuel energy. These results indicate that P doping to NiFe-based selenides is a promising strategy to achieve highly efficient electrocatalysts for practical overall water splitting.

A highly efficient and stable electrocatalyst of P-Ni075Fe0.25Se2 has been successfully prepared on nickel foam. Systematic experiments indicate that the electronic structure of Fe can be independently tuned by P doping without affecting Ni. Thereafter, the energy barrier of the rate-limiting step is changed from 2.09 eV to 1.97 eV at optimized active sites with significantly enhanced reaction efficiency. Not only newly created active sites but also enhanced intrinsic activity by P doping contribute to the substantially improved OER performance. As a result, the self-supported P-Ni075Fe0.25Se2 electrode exhibited an ultralow overpotential of 156 mV at 10 mA cm−2 in 1 M KOH with a small Tafel slope of 19.5 mV dec−1, coupled with remarkable long-term durability (1000 h at 300 mA cm−2). More intriguingly, a two-electrode water-alkali electrolyzer assembled with P-Ni0.75Fe0.25Se2 and MoNi4/MoO2 realizes a fascinating catalytic performance for overall water splitting with a current density of 10 mA cm−2 achieved by a small cell voltage of 1.45 V and can stably work for up to 1000 h at a relatively high current density of 100 mA cm−2, superior to RuO2 || MoNi4/MoO2. The strategy for engineering electronic structure independently may be extended to other multicomponent chalcogenides, and the high activity and stability of the as-prepared electrode make Ni075Fe0.25Se2 a promising non-noble metal candidate for OER in energy conversion and storage for practical applications.

H. Liu and J. J. Wang conceptualized and supervised the research; Y. Huang performed all the experiments and wrote the manuscript revised by J. J. Wang; X. L. Liu and T. Tan performed the theoretical calculations and analysis. L. W. Jiang participated in various aspects of the experiments and discussions. All authors discussed the results and commented on the manuscript.
